channel.title: Gaming PC Build
channel.description:
Okay. I'm looking for a gaming PC build.
Me and my Dad have been talking, and he thinks an appropriate budget would be at $600.
Now, with the budget set at $600, I'm looking for a build that will give me the ability to play any new game I buy on at least medium settings, without lag.
I don't need a monitor, but I am going to need an OS with this build. I don't know much about building PC's, so if you could give me any extra information, I'd really appreciate it.
So, could anyone help me out with a good gaming PC build for $600?
Also, if this is in the wrong section, could a moderator please move it?

item.title: Gaming PC Build
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

Go to Newegg and get a $450 or so combo DIY build along with a gtx 560 or something, then you get all the pieces you need in the mail at once, and it even has videos over how to put your build together.

It will play any new game on high or ultra at a pretty decent frame rate.

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming PC Build
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“TimeBroken, post:20, topic:447858”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=550749.msg4041188#msg4041188 date=1341648641]
It was all looking good… until you got to the processor, ew.

Oh and should’ve bought OEM Windows 7 really.
[/quote]

Processor has gotten lots of good reviews from what I’ve seen. I haven’t seen any real problems with it at all tbh.
The place I bought the stuff gives a free copy of Windows 7 for $1k+ purchases.[/quote]

The processor should be fine for the next couple of years.

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming PC Build
item.dc:creator: @TimeBroken TimeBroken
item.description:
@TimeBroken wrote:

I know this is a late reply, but we ended up spending about 2x the budget. I just wanted to let you guys who helped me out know what I ended up doing.

Tower: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16811119197
Motherboard: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16813131767
Video Card: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16814130687
Power Supply: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16817171039
Processor: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16819103961
Memory Cards (2): http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820148346
Hard Drive: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16822136769
DVD: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16827106352
Windows 7: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16832116716

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming PC Build
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:12, topic:447858”]of course optional, but if you don’t want to risk too much or you feel overwhelmed do what I did:

bought $900 fully ATX kickass i7 HP desktop. Hp was awesome and documented how to remove every component for cleaning/replacing, it was a breeze. Processor and RAM included were excellent, the card was pretty good also.

Swapped psu, swapped gpu (GTX 560 TI) and then a few months later swapped cases (Antec 902). Swapping the case was what taught me the most about computers and made me feel more comfortable working on them.

Pressing the power button and instead of bursting into flames I saw tons of blue lights and all the fans turn on and was like PHEW! But I heard a weird buzzing that sounded like a screw fell in my psu and I got worried, only to find out it was my audio cable tag lightly touching my card fan.[/quote]

Same here. Although, I was afraid that my PSU wasn’t working, and the only way to test it (without having the rest of the components) was to use a paperclip to complete a circuit in the plug. I was an idiot and did it with the power still on.

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming PC Build
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

of course optional, but if you don’t want to risk too much or you feel overwhelmed do what I did:

bought $900 fully ATX kickass i7 HP desktop. Hp was awesome and documented how to remove every component for cleaning/replacing, it was a breeze. Processor and RAM included were excellent, the card was pretty good also.

Swapped psu, swapped gpu (GTX 560 TI) and then a few months later swapped cases (Antec 902). Swapping the case was what taught me the most about computers and made me feel more comfortable working on them.

Pressing the power button and instead of bursting into flames I saw tons of blue lights and all the fans turn on and was like PHEW! But I heard a weird buzzing that sounded like a screw fell in my psu and I got worried, only to find out it was my audio cable tag lightly touching my card fan.

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming PC Build
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Here’s what you need:

Case
Power Supply
Motherboard
Processor
RAM
Hard Drive
Video Card
Monitor
Keyboard
Mouse
[DVD Drive] (Optional, but highly recommended)

item.title: Gaming PC Build
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“Kidpaparoach, post:1, topic:448007”]Don’t buy a quadcore, quad cores are decent but I got my quad-core just over 2 years ago their getting old.

In my personal opinion what matters the most is the processor then the gfx card then the ram then w.e. else. Sometimes ram comes before gfx card, it just depends what you use your pc/laptop for but proccessor = the most important part imo don’t buy anything below i5 for a proccessor.

I saw somewhere $650 for i7, 8gb ram, 1gb gfx card… , 1tb hdd windows 64bit etc, it was a real bargain so i’m sure if i can find something like that on the interwebs you can too if you search hard enough or if you go to a store thats got a closing down sale. Well i can’t remember if it was $650 or £650 tbh >.<[/quote]
Don’t listen to this guy. He has absolutely no idea what the hell hes talking about.

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming PC Build
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

Well I found this and I will probably buy it:
http://shopping.hp.com/en_US/home-office/-/products/Desktops/HP-Pavilion/QW744AA?HP-Pavilion-p7-1202-Desktop-PC&aoid=41841&srccode=cii_23393768&cpncode=27-129425441-2
$480 isn’t bad for those specs.

Operating system:
Genuine Windows® 7 Home Premium 64

Processor:
AMD Quad-Core A6-3670K APU (2.7 GHz 4 MB L2 cache )
2.7 GHz
4 MB L2 cache

Memory:
6 GB 1333 MHz DDR3 - Supports up to 16GB DDR3 memory
4 DIMM

Hard drive:
1 TB SATA (7200 rpm)

Graphics:
AMD Radeon HD 6530D (up to 2.99 GB)

Optical drive:
SuperMulti DVD Burner

Keyboard & Mouse:
USB keyboard
USB optical mouse

Its cheap because it has an AMD processor.

Probably isn’t for gaming but it looks like a nice computer.

Read full topic
